Nitrogen oxide (NO), one of the major air pollutants derived from the combustion of fossil fuels, has been gradually implemented with more strict emission standards in recent decades. The traditional technologies of NO removal suffer from harsher operating conditions and higher operating costs. In this case, shifting toward more eco-friendly, sustainable methods is pursued to reduce costs and increase efficiency in NO removal. With the increase of green and renewable electricity, it is a promising way to use electrochemical technology for NO conversion into more valuable chemicals, such as ammonia (NH3), urea (CH4N2O), amines and amides, etc. In this concept, researchers have made great efforts to develop different electrocatalytic systems. In this paper, we summarize the current important progress of electrocatalytic NO reduction reaction (NORR). As the concerning multi-step mechanism is complex, the priority is to screen and design efficient electrocatalysts for a certain target product. Especially for NO-to-NH3 conversion, we divide a large chapter to emphasize the advances made in mechanisms, catalyst and electrolyte. Meanwhile, the emerging CN coupling reactions for organism synthesis further drastically increases reaction complexity, as the co-reduction of two distinct reactants involves more intermediates and multiple cross-reactive pathways. The catalyst and microenvironments must be cleverly regulated and optimized to control CN bond formation. Moreover, the current challenges and future perspectives will be proposed as well to accelerate the research and development of related technologies, leading to a green and sustainable production of N-based chemicals. Graphical abstract We summarize the current important progress of electrocatalytic NO reduction reaction (NORR). Especially for NO-to-NH3 conversion, we divide a large chapter to emphasize the advances made in mechanisms, catalyst, electrolyte, and reactor design. Meanwhile, the emerging CN coupling reactions for organism synthesis further drastically increases reaction complexity, as the co-reduction of two distinct reactants involves more intermediates and multiple cross-reactive pathways. Image, graphical abstract Keywords NO electroreduction NH3 synthesis C-N coupling energy conversion Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxide (NO), as one of harmful air pollutants, is mainly produced from industrial boilers, vehicles and incinerators [1,2]. At present, great efforts have been made for NO removal to achieve stringent emission standards [3,4]. Based on NO generation process, three different methods are applied to NO emission, which are pre-combustion, combustion, and post-combustion. Wide numbers of researches focus on developing effective post-combustion technologies [5–7], included selective catalytic reduction (SCR), selective noncatalytic reduction (SNCR), catalytic ozone oxidation, and wet scrubbing. However, the above reactions are usual limited by harsh conditions with expensive noble-metal catalysts or extra sacrificial chemical agent. Besides, by-products without higher value-added from the reactions can hardly offset part of the operation costs. And even more, dealing with some of the by-products requires additional costs. In response to the growing demand for sustainability, it is urgent to develop low-cost and environment-friendly NO removal methods. With the rapid development of clean-renewable energy [8–11], energy storage in form of chemical products makes it more attractive to reduce NO into high value-added chemicals, such as NH3 [12], HNO x [13] and N-containing organic compounds (Fig. 1 ) [14,15]. As opposed to traditional thermal-based processes, shifting toward electrochemical processes powered by clean and renewable electricity promises approaches for addressing environmental issues. Ammonia, an important chemical vector and raw material, is widely used in various fields, including chemical synthesis, pharmaceutical chemistry, and agriculture [16–18]. Besides, due to the high hydrogen proportion, carbon-free content and easy liquidation, it is also selected as a kind of clean energy carrier in fuel cells [19–21]. Currently, the large-scale production of NH3 relies heavily on the conventional Haber-Bosch (H-B) process driven by fossil fuels (N2 + 3H2 → 2NH3), which is limited at elevated temperature and high pressure (400–500 ℃ and 15–25 MPa) and consumes about 1 % of the global energy consumption [22,23]. It is also worth noting that H2 supply in this process from steam reforming of methane will result in a large emission of CO2 and other greenhouse gases. As a promising alternative, the electrochemical reductions of different N-sources (NO, NO3 −, NO2 −, N2, etc.) for NH3 synthesis avoid the above disadvantages. Although N2 is easily accessible, the triple bond of NN is extremely inert, which makes the development of catalysts difficult [24,25]. Based on reaction kinetics and thermodynamics, both nitrate and nitrite are favorable for the synthesis of NH3 in a liquid-phase environment [26], but the source is highly dependent on wastewater recycling. NO can be directly involved in the formation of CN bonds as an electron acceptor or donor, simplifying the pathway to synthesize NH3 [27]. In addition, the conversion of NO-to-NH3 from industrial waste gases can be used in the desulfurization process to achieve a synergistic demineralization and desulfurization process [28]. The electrochemical NO-to-NH3 conversion involves 5H+/5e− transfer (NO +5H+ + 5e− ↔ NH3, E° = 0.71 V vs reversible hydrogen electrode (VRHE)), and can realize zero-carbon emissions and NH3 generation [22]. Owing to lower dissociation energy of NO bond (607 kJ mol−1) and favorable reaction kinetics, compared to NN bond (945 kJ·mol−1), NO protonation can be conducted at low-temperature. In this process, NO could easily capture protons devoted from water, avoiding the extra supply of H2 [29]. However, the competing HER (hydrogen evolution reaction) with a 2H+/2e− process and the low solubility of NO (1.94×10−6 mol·cm−3·atm−1, 25 ℃ in water) [30] are great challenges for electrochemical NO-to-NH3 conversion. Therefore, the rational electrocatalytic systems and catalysts with high selectivity and activity remain to be a critical issue. While state-of-the-art electrocatalysts have achieved the high selectivity and reaction rate for electrochemical NO-to-NH3 process, further expanding the species and scope of products with higher value-added is limited in above systems starting solely from NO and H2O as the reactants [31]. The CN coupling reactions by combining NORR with the electrochemical conversion of different C-sources can synthesize CN bond-containing compounds, significantly increasing the diversity of products [32]. A few studies have reported to successfully construct the CN bond, such as urea (CO(NH2)2), amino acids, and cyclohexanone oxime. The industrial production of these organics generally involves a multistep process in which NH3 is necessary [33], resulting in more greenhouse gas emissions and energy consumption. Thus, the electrochemical co-reduction of C-sources and NO is a green and atomic-economy strategy to replace the traditional synthetic method of N-containing organics. Particularly, urea is produced by the energy- and capital-intensive H-B and Bosch-Meiser (B-M) processes, which is the most important nitrogen fertilizer and key chemical raw material for the polymer industry [34,35]. However, the corresponding electrocatalytic synthesis for these organics are all multi-electron transfer processes involving diverse reactants and reactions. Therefore, the co-reduction of NO with carbon sources to the specific N-containing product remains a challenge, too. In this review, we firstly summarize the recent theoretical studies about NORR mechanisms and experimental studies for screening efficient catalysts toward NH3 formation, according to the factors, such as the rate-determining step (RDS), potential-determining step (PDS), activity trend, and selectivity at varying potentials. Then, the advances made in catalysts design under different temperature ranges will be described in detail. Moreover, the activity toward various application scenarios will be also reviewed over the past decade. We have dedicated a section to discuss indirect NORR process, emphasizing the relationship between activity and ferrous complex electrolyte. Meanwhile, other higher value-added products with electrochemical CN coupling process are also given much attention, including urea, amino acid, and cyclohexanone oxime. Finally, the current challenges, prospective strategies and emerging opportunities for the large-scale application of NORR are proposed to shed light on the future direction at the end of this review. 2 Direct ammonia synthesis 2.1 Pathways for NO electroreduction The process of NO-to-NH3 is influenced by various factors such as the concentration of NO, potential, electrolyte condition and electrode material. And the corresponding products of possible pathway could not only be N2O, N2, NH2OH, NH3 and other N-containing products, but also compete with indispensable HER process. For NO-to-NH3 conversion as shown in Fig. 2a , the process of NO-to-NH3 involves five electrons coupled with six protons transfer corresponding theoretical potential of 0.71 VRHE [36]. The conversion efficiency for NH3 is mainly enslaved by the overpotential, the selectivity and Faradaic efficiency (FE) toward NH3. In consequence, the process of NO-to-NH3 with diverse possible reactive pathways is complex [37]. The applied potential is a critical factor to control the product selectivity [38,39], and the thermodynamic potential for different products are as follows: 2NO + 4(H+ + e−) → N2 + 2 H2O, E0 = 1.68 V; 2NO + 2(H+ + e−) → N2O + 2 H2O, E0 = 1.59 V; NO + 5(H+ + e−) → NH3 + H2O, E0 = 0.71 V; NO + 3(H+ + e−) → NH2OH, E0 = 0.38 V; 2(H+ + e−) → H2, E 0 = 0 V. At least five protons derived from the electrolyte are necessary, so the lower pH is more conducive to the process of NO-to-NH3. On the other hand, the aqueous composition significantly influences the catalytic performance in electrocatalytic reactions by affecting reaction kinetics, reaction process, selectivity, and stability. Alkali metal cations alter interfacial electric fields and the organization of water molecules, which can block active sites or stabilize reaction intermediates [40]. Anions like phosphate can adsorb onto catalyst surfaces, inhibiting reactions by blocking active sites [41]. While the effects of electrolytes on catalytic performance are well-documented, the complexity of interactions and the dynamic nature of electrolytes during reactions present ongoing challenges for researchers in optimizing electrocatalytic systems [42]. In order to design catalysts rationally, it is crucial to establish theoretical models in an appropriate environment to clarify the reaction pathways as well as the reaction products [43]. The interaction of NO with metal surfaces has been a traditional model system in the gas-solid reaction system. However, when components other than protons are involved in the reaction (e.g., Li+, EDTA, O2, etc.), the reaction process will be more complex to the point of being difficult to specify [44]. Here, we focus on the key steps in the reduction of NO to NH3, as well as the main competing reaction, HER. The initial and crucial step in NORR is the adsorption of NO. Ren et al. examined the pathway of NORR on topological nodal-line semimetal Cu2Si monolayer [36]. Three adsorption configurations on four type adsorption sites were taken into account, namely, N-end, O-end, NO-side. Then, four effective NO adsorption configurations on Cu2Si were screened by the DFT calculations. Based on four adsorption sites, eight possible reaction pathways were constructed as shown in Fig. 2. Further calculation results proved that Si atom can reduce the NO adsorption strength and thus facilitate the protonation of *NO, removing the thermodynamic energy barrier. Concerning the pathway of N2O formation, Prof. Jeff Greeley et al. demonstrated the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism on the Pt (111) surface [45], through which solvated NO interact with *NO to form trans-(NO)2, followed by *NONOH to N2O conversion. Therefore, they emphasized the importance of the aqueous electrochemical environment in the reduction of NO on electrode surfaces. However, different catalysts have their unique catalytic mechanisms. Long et al. proposed the adsorption of *NO on Ag (111) is much weaker than on Pt [46], resulting the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism to be easier for N2O production (Fig. 3 ). For further reduction of N2O, Li et al. concluded that the fundamental limited steps are weak N2OH* binding and strong correlation of OH* and O* binding energies over transition metals [47]. In addition, they also proved that Cu shows the exceptionally high NH3 selectivity with low N2O formation, which is attributed to avoid the coupling reaction of transition states and facile N* protonation. In recent years, there has been a lot of research about the first protonated intermediate, and its nature plays an important role in determining pathway on different catalysts [48,49]. The thermodynamically stable intermediate of first protonated step is *NHO or *NOH in NORR process. *NOH protonates to form *N by electrochemically assisted NOH bond cleavage, and *N is the precursor state to form NH4 +. Whereas, *NOH protonates to form to *HNOH, which is the precursor state to form NH3OH+. Katsounaros et al. and Clayborne et al. studied the electrochemical reduction of adsorbed NO on Pt(111) and Pt(100) electrodes, and verified that the stability of the first hydrogenation product (*NHO or *NOH) and thus the reaction mechanism strongly depends on the *NO coverage and the surface facet [50]. Furthermore, Deshpande et al. analyzed more influencing factors on selectivity trends in NORR process, such as coverage, ensemble and solvation [51]. Based on kinetic calculations, *NOH and *NHO may form in comparable quantities on Pt3Sn (111). Same as the results on Pt (111), the NO bond-breaking barrier for *NOH is relatively small. But, the oxophilic Sn atom stabilizes *NHO to favor the following reduction (*HNOH-*NH2OHNH3OH+). Prof. Jan Rossmeisl’s group also elucidate selectivity and activity of various catalyst for NORR, and classified metals by the binding of *NO versus *H at low potential [52]. Based limiting potential for NO-to-NH3 against the adsorption energy of *N (ΔG*N), Cu prefers *NOH while *NHO is formed on Ag or Au in the hydrogenation of *NO. Further results show that Cu is the most active catalyst to produce NH3 and the potential limiting step is the *NO protonates to form *NOH. Guo et al. found that a key factor for selectivity control is the first step of NO* protonation over hcp-Co (hexagonal close-packed cobalt), fcc-Co (face-centered cubic cobalt), and Co-SAC (cobalt single-atom) [53]. As shown in Fig. 4 , NOH* production is favored on hcp-Co and fcc-Co, whereas HNO* production is favored on Co-SAC. The result is closely related to the strong vertical adsorption of NO on the former and the moderate adsorption of NO on the latter. Moreover, they found that the superior activity for NH3 production on hcp-Co can be attributed to its facile electron and proton transfer and a stronger lateral suppression effect from NO* over fcc-Co. HER, as a main competing reaction to NORR, is a more preferred process. The stronger binding of *NO than *H over catalyst surfaces has been regarded as an important property for the high selectivity of the NORR against the HER [54,55]. The Prof. Jan Rossmeisl’s works proved that metals with strong *H binding energy significantly suppress NH3 formation, especially at potential below 0 VRHE [52]. Carro et al. established a direct relationship between the NO-philic and H-philic properties with comprehensive DFT analysis [55]. Importantly, NO is adsorbed strongly on most metals, most significant for the transition d-metals. But HER is inevitable at potential far below 0 VRHE. Unlike metal catalysts, single-atom catalysts (SACs) offer a unique coordination environment with outstanding merits of ∼ 100 % atom utilization efficiency and strong metal-support interactions, which is an ideal model to unveil the mechanism at atomic level. Niu et al. explored 8 thermodynamically stable transition metals SACs supported on C2N (TM-C2N) [56]. It is found that TM-C2N with the suppression byproduct of H2 can sufficiently adsorb and activate NO molecule, and then effectively convert NO toward NH3. Real catalytic environments are generally much more complex and involve a variety of factors. Most studies use simplified models to calculate thermodynamics for NORR process. As a result, it is often far from the actual electrochemical catalytic environment. Analyzing electrocatalysts and tracking NO before and after the catalytic process are important for identifying the real active sites and finding out more about the intermediate transition state. In-situ characterizations should be conducted in order to get more accurate results. 2.2 Electrocatalysts advance at ambient conditions In the process of electrochemical NO-to-NH3, NO with a nitrogen-oxygen single bond structure will coordinate with the core elements of the catalyst. It leads to the reduction of the bond energy between N and O atoms and the weakening of the stability of the NO molecular structure [57]. In essence, the catalyst reduces the energy barrier of the NO molecular fracture reaction and finally catalyzes the total NORR process. At present, the developed catalysts for electrochemical NO-to-NH3 can be roughly divided into four categories, including metal elemental catalysts, SACs, metal-based catalyst and bimetal-based catalysts. 2.2.1 Metal elemental catalysts Metal elemental catalysts with zero-valent catalyze the reaction through free electrons, unsaturated coordination check points or crystal plane characteristics on the metal surface. Since most of these catalysts can be obtained directly through commercial channels, high-efficiency catalysts can be quickly verified and screened based on theoretical calculation results. In 2020, Choi et al. examined 20 wt. % Au/C as catalyst for NORR process, obtaining a NH3 yield rate of 2.91 µmol·cm–2·h–1 at −0.30 VRHE [58]. Based on global energy minimum criterion, Long et al. compared the activity trend of NORR over 10 transition metals, and predicted Cu as the most active and selective catalyst [59]. The corresponding experiments were confirmed with Cu foam and Cu foil electrodes by comparison of a Pt foil electrode. As shown in Fig. 5 , a record-high NH3 yield rate of 517.1 µmol·cm–2·h–1 was achieved at −0.9 VRHE by the Cu foam, which also showed a long-term stability for 100 h. Liu et al. reported an in-situ formed hierarchical porous Cu nanowire array monolithic electrode, which ensembled in a pressurized electrolyzer [60]. This system delivers an ampere-level NH3 partial current density of 1007 mA·cm–2 with a high FE(NH3) of 96.1 %, an NH3 yield rate of 10.5 mmol·cm–2·h–1, and excellent stability of over 100 h electrolysis at 1000 mA·cm–2. Recently, Jiao et al. [61]. and Krzywda et al. [62]. also carried out similar experiments and obtained similar results by using Cu electrodes. The experiments from Jiao et al. also investigated other commercial transition metal catalysts, such as Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Pd, Ag, and Pt particles. Among these catalysts, Cu exhibited a best NH3 selectivity at high reaction rates (up to ∼400 mA·cm–2 in a flow cell), but which remains far from satisfactory (9.3 × 10–7 mol·cm–2·s–1 of the US Department of Energy) [16,63,64]. Although the commercial Cu-based catalyst has been validated experimentally and theoretically for efficient electrocatalytic NORR, other metal catalysts can also improve NORR activity by regulating unsaturated coordination check points or crystal plane characteristics. Through calculating the energy gaps of RDS in HER and NORR on Ti, V, Cu, Au, and Ag, Zhao et al. confirmed that the energy gaps of RDS for HER on Ni are much higher than that of NOR, with the largest energy difference among all involved metals, indicating a high selectivity toward the nitrogen product. Then they designed five single-crystal Ni foils with different surface orientations, achieving ∼100 % of FE(NH3) on Ni (210) facet [65]. To improve the catalytic performances, designing electrocatalysts with specific components, microstructures, morphologies and is an efficient tool [66–68]. Prof. Wang’s group prepared hexagonal-close-packed (hcp) and face-centered cubic (fcc) Co nanosheets by hydrothermal method, and compared the performance of electrochemical NORR [69]. The hcp phase of Co nanosheets exhibits a high NH3 yield of 439.50 μmol·cm–2·h–1 and a Faraday efficiency of 72.58 %. Based on NO-TPD and theoretical calculation, the better catalytic activity originates from NO adsorption capacity and facile proton shuttle effect. Cheon et al. tried to circumvent the mass transport issue by using a gas diffusion electrode (GDE) [70]. Nanoscale zero-valent iron was explored as the NORR electrocatalyst and verified a high-performance for NH3 formation. 2.2.2 Single-atom catalysts In heterogeneous catalysis, the interaction between the reactants and the catalyst occurs at the active sites on the solid surface. Increasing the surface atom ratio of the active components is the key to directly improve the catalytic efficiency [71]. SACs have garnered significant attention due to their exceptional atom utilization and unique properties. When the dispersion of active particles reaches the size of a single atom, SACs will have many new characteristics, such as rapidly increasing surface free energy, quantum size effect, unsaturated coordination environment and metal carrier interaction [72]. On the macro level, it can change the adsorption and desorption selectivity of active components on the catalyst to different molecules, thereby affecting the reaction dynamics. Cu-SACs have been theoretically studied to achieve the high-performing NORR. Chen et al. prepared Cu1/MoS2 catalyst (single-atomic Cu anchored on MoS2) with Cu1-S3 motifs, which can effectively activate and protonate NO to NH3 [73]. And it exhibits a high NH3 yield rate of 337.5 μmol·cm−2·h−1 with a FE of 90.6 % at −0.6 VRHE. Besides the high activity and selectivity, Cu1/MoS2 also presents the excellent cycling and long-term stability. Combined experiments and theoretical calculations reveal that the high activity results from the effective activation and hydrogenation of NO by Cu1-S3 motifs. In studies of Prof. Wang’s group, they proposed an atomic copper–iron dual-site electrocatalyst anchored on N-doped carbon (CuFe DS/NC) [74]. Due to the optimized rate-determining step and the accelerated protonation process, it can significantly enhance the performance of NO-to-NH3 conversion (FE(NH3), 90 %; NH3 yield rate, 112.52 µmol·cm−2·h−1). In addition, a proof-of-concept Zn-NO battery was assembled by using CuFe DS/NC as the cathode, and output a power density of 2.30 mW·cm−2. Peng et al. screened a family of electro catalysts with single-atom (Al, Mn, Fe, Cu and Nb) sites supported on B, N co-doped carbon nanotubes (M-SA/BNC) [75]. Particularly, the Nb-SA/BNC catalyst delivers a best NH3 yield rate of 295.2 µmol·cm−2·h−1, which approaches the US Department of Energy target. 2.2.3 Metal-based catalyst Compared with metal single-element catalysts, metal oxide catalysts and other metal derivatives are more stable, cost-effective, and selective for NH3. Shao et al. synthesized copper oxide (CuO) nanosheet catalyst with a high specific surface area and abundant defects [76]. This catalyst exhibited a remarkable 92.1 % FE(NH3) in a flow cell and an NH3 production rate of 7356 µmol·cm−2·h−1 at −0.26 VRHE. Prof. Sun’s group successively developed two cobalt-based catalysts of CoP [77] and CoS [78], and verified their activity under the same conditions. Then, they deduced FeP would be a promising catalyst for NH3 production [79]. And the result exhibits high performance with an NH3 yield rate of 85.62 μmol·cm−2·h−1 (FE(NH3), 8.49 %). Besides, they found the honeycomb carbon nanofiber can also be applied to NORR process and showing great stability for 10-hour continuous electrolysis [80]. In their recent study [81], TiO2− x nanoarray on Ti plate (TiO2− x /TP) was designed for high-efficiency NH3 electrosynthesis from low-concentration NO (Fig. 6 ). Based DFT calculations, the adsorption energy of *H on the oxygen vacancies (OVs) of TiO2 (−0.44 eV) is much larger than that of *NO on TiO2− x (−2.14 eV). Thus, the sites of OVs on TiO2− x favor NO adsorption property and efficiently suppress the competing HER. The optimal performance attains a great yield rate of 460.1 μmol·cm−2·h−1 and high FE(NH3) of 92.5 % at −0.4 VRHE. Considering that both Cu and TiO2 can effectively inhibit HER and activate NO, Chen et al. prepared Cu/P-TiO2 electrocatalyst by loading ultrafine Cu nanoparticles on porous TiO2 surface and evaluated its catalytic activity for NH3 product [82]. 2.2.4 Bimetal-based catalysts In order to address the limitations of the unidirectional catalytic ability of conventional electrocatalysts (stability, activity, cost, coordination environment, etc.), catalysts employing two or more active sites are able to balance each other's advantages and disadvantages [83]. Shi et al. synthesized a series of Ru-doped Cu materials via in-situ electroreduction conversion strategy and optimized the catalysts as Ru0.05Cu0.95 with the optimum activity of NORR [84]. Experimental and theoretical simulations unveil that the decreased d-band center of surface Cu caused by Ru doping reduces the reaction energy of the rate-limiting hydrogenation step and the desorption energy of NH3, inducing the improvement of NORR performance. Furthermore, Ru nanosheets with low coordination numbers (Ru-LCN) [85] RuGa intermetallic compounds (RuGa IMCs) [86] were developed recently as catalysts for NORR according to their reports. The optimal activity is obtained with a remarkable NH3 yield rate of 641.2 µmol·cm−2·h−1. Wu at al. prepared a CoNiO x @Cu electrode with the merits of facilitating NO adsorption and reducing the reaction energy barrier [87]. A single electrolyzer, via coupling cathodic NORR with anodic NO electrooxidation simultaneously, is assembled to realize electrocatalytic disproportionation of NO and inhibit competitive HER. Relying on above strategy, a record high NH3 yield rate of 1176.5 μmol·cm−2·h−1 with FE(NH3) ≈100 % was achieved at −0.68 VRHE for continuous 36 h stable operating (Fig. 7 ). Bai et al. designed various hollow Cu2O@CoMn2O4 nanoreactors to verify the void-confinement effect on NORR reaction [88]. Through theoretical calculation and experimental verification, the Cu sites of Cu2O@CoMn2O4 nanoreactors are favorable for the formation of *NOH intermediates, resulting in a remarkable NORR activity. Prof. Shanmugam’s group constructed two kinds of shell-core catalysts (Ni@NC [89] and NiNC@CF [90]), a layer of carbon-wrapped catalysts encapsulated with Ni nanoparticles as core. By conducting a series of control tests, the best performance from Ni@NC was attained at the lowest overpotentials of 0.16 VRHE. Moreover, The NiNC@CF catalyst exhibited an NH3 yield rate of 94 μmol·cm−2·h−1 with 87 % FE(NH3). Prof. Sun’s group also developed a nickel-based phosphides (Ni2P/CP) for NO-to-NH3 conversion, which attains a similar activity to the above Ni@NC catalyst [91]. 2.3 Electrocatalysts advance at medium and high temperature Although great progress has been made in electrocatalytic NO-to-NH3 conversion under ambient conditions, the additional separation process of NH3 product from the liquid electrolyte is a limitation for commercial applications [23,92–94]. And various side reactions seriously hinder the control of product selectivity and the study of reaction mechanisms. To overcome the above shortcomings, there has been a growing interest in using medium and high temperature electrolysis cells to realize NO-to-NH3 conversion. Furthermore, higher temperatures can effectively reduce the reaction activation energy, thereby accelerating the reaction rate. However, only a few studies have been reported regarding its effectiveness. Zhang et al. designed a molten alkali electrolysis reactor for NO-to-NH3 conversion at 220 ℃ [95]. By a tandem process of reduction and oxidation, the NO was first oxidized to soluble NO x − on the anode, then the generated NO x − transported to the cathode and followed by an efficient reduction to produce NH3. By adjusting the conditions, a high NH3 production rate (6.5 mmol·cm−2·h−1) with 98.9 % FE(NH3) was achieved in molten alkali with Ni foam as cathode and Ni mesh as anode. Based on an oxide ionic conductor of a solid-state cell, the idea to reduce NO x at the cathode is proposed for higher temperature systems (>500 ℃). A schematic diagram of the basic concept for electrochemical NH3 synthesis using NO and H2O in an electrolysis cell based on the solid electrolyte with oxygen ion conductivity is shown in Fig. 8 [96]. Solid Oxide Fuel Cells (SOFC) typically use chalcogenide oxides as electrode materials. Compared to precious metals, chalcocite oxides are less expensive and have good redox stability [97,98]. Recently, Kwon et al. used NO and H2O in a solid oxide electrolysis cell based on an LSGM (La0.9Sr0.1Ga0.8Mg0.2O3-δ) solid electrolyte with oxygen ion conductivity for NO-to-NH3 conversion [96]. STFC (SrTi0.3Fe0.55Co0.15O3-δ), a perovskite ceramic oxide with high electrical conductivity, was prepared as an anode. Meanwhile, the modified STFC-GDC composite electrode by adding gadolinium-doped ceria (Ce0.9Gd0.1O2−δ) was used as a cathode for NH3 synthesis. Under atmospheric conditions, a maximum NH3 yield rate of 1885 μmol·cm–2·h–1 (FE(NH3), 34.8 %) was achieved at 650 °C. In our previous work [99], a tubular solid-state fuel cell was designed with the configuration of La1-xSrMnO (LSM) as the cathode, yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) as the electrolyte, and Ni-doped YSZ catalyst as the anode. To enhance NO-to-NH3 conversion, a series of Fe-loaded carbon materials were fabricated and applied to NORR process. In the condition of 1 % O2 the results presented a high NO removal efficiency of 60 % with NH3 formation. In addition, much studies have focused only on the NO removal rate and to improve selectivity for harmless N2, ignoring the process of NO-to-NH3 [100–102]. NO obtain electrons at cathode and then are directly reduced to N2 and O2 – ions. The formed N2 is released to the outside of the cathode, while the O2 – ions are transferred across the electrolyte and are anodized to O2 at the anode ultimately [103–107]. It is worth noting that the loss of proton donors during this process results in the reduction of NO to only N2 [108,109]. But it is still informative for the process of NO-to-NH3. 3 Indirect ammonia synthesis Much effort was devoted to designed efficient catalysts for NORR, focusing on improving the selectivity and rate of NH3. Although current research has achieved an excellent Faraday efficiency (FE(NH3)≈100 %) as well as a high NH3 rate (1.53 mmol·cm–2·h–1). The high purity and concentration NO was used to direct reduce in above reports. Considering technical cost and feasibility to concentrate NO from the exhaust gas, direct electrochemical reduction of NO deviates from the application scenario for reusing the exhaust NO gas. For low concentrations of NO in flue gas, an electrode-electrolyte design-based approach is proposed for electrochemical NH3 synthesis. In detail, metal (Fe, Co, Zn, etc.) complexes are selected as capture agents to quickly capture the low-concentration NO in flue gas [110,111], enhanced removal and solubility of NO. Meanwhile, the complexed NO can be electrochemically reduced to NH3, accompanied by metal complex regeneration. Tables 1 and 2 Kim et al. designed an electrochemical reduction system by using Fe(II)(EDTA) and phosphate as electrolyte [112]. In a three-electrode cell (Fig. 9 ), Ag foil, Pt foil and glassy carbon (GC) were first used as cathode to verify the conversion of NO-to-NH3. With NO gas saturated electrolyte, the Ag electrode shows the superior activity, and exhibits nearly 100 % FE(NH3) in potential ranges of −0.15 to −0.29 VRHE. For enhancing catalytic performance, they fabricated nanostructured silver (Agn) and investigated its structural effect for NH3 production. In a flow cell, the CA experiments on the Agn electrodes showed the maximum NH3 production rate of 0.36 mmol·cm–2·h–1 with ∼100 % FE(NH3) at −0.165 VRHE. Different from the above system, Prof. Sun’s group not only designed and prepared several catalysts for electrochemical catalytic conversion of NO-to-NH3 [113–117], but also assembled corresponding Zn-NO batteries. In NO-saturated 0.1 M Na2SO4 + 0.05 mM Fe(II)-EDTA solution, the prepared NiO nanosheet array on Ti mesh (NiO/TM) achieved the highest FE(NH3) of up to 90 % with a NH3 yield of 0.13 mmol·cm−2·h−1 [113]. Under the same environment, they prepared an amorphous B2.6C catalyst supported on a TiO2 nanoarray [114], attaining the maximum NH3 yield of 0.19 mmol·cm−2·h−1 with 87.6 % FE(NH3). Based on the DFT calculation, dangling bonds of three-coordinated boron and carbon (Fig. 10a ) can bond with NO strongly (Fig. 10b). According to Mulliken population analysis, NO molecule can be activated once external electrons are injected (Fig. 10d). And the first protonation of NO is the potential determining step in almost all results (Fig. 10e). The hydrogenation of NO through proton-coupled electron transfer favors the NOH* pathway or the HNO* pathway, which is also consistent with the previously reported DFT results on the direct NO-reduction system. In our previous work [118], ferrous citrate (Fe(II)-Cit) was selected as electrolyte to avoid the influence of EDTA on the detection of NH3. The cathode with loading Au/rGO was prepared by an electro-deposition method and showed excellent activities. Remarkably, the maximum FE(NH3) with 98.3 % was at pH = 1. Qi at al. anchored nonporous VN film on carbon fiber (np-VN/CF) to catalyze the NO-to-NH3 conversion in 0.1 M HCl solution containing 0.5 mM iron(II) sodium benzoate (Fe(II)SB) [119]. The as-prepared catalyst achieves a maximal FE(NH3) of 85 % with a record-level yield rate of 3.78 mmol·cm–2·h–1, and maintains an excellent activity over 40 h. 4 Organonitrogen compounds synthesis The CN bond structure exists in many fertilizers, commodities and fine chemicals (such as urea, amines and amides, etc.) [33,121–123], but the current synthesis route has complex or high energy consumption problems. Although, electrochemical synthesis of CN bond from NO with various carbon resources is a promising alternative to traditional routes. It is still a great challenge to steer the pathway of CN formation out of many. As such, only a few studies have been reported in recent years. In this section, we review the progress of electrocatalytic synthesis of CN organic compounds using NO as nitrogen source. 4.1 Urea Urea, a vital fertilizer, is the first organic compound obtained by artificially synthesizing inorganic substances [124]. It is widely used in non-agricultural fields such as agriculture, medicine, textiles, and energy carriers [125,126]. Currently, the industrial production of urea is through the reaction of CO2 and NH3, which requires huge energy consumption [34]. In view of the extensive study on the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) to a variety of mono‐carbon (C1) and multi-carbon (C2+) products [127,128], the electrochemical co-reduction of NO and CO2 not only inherit the advantages of NORR and CO2RR but also provides more possibilities for broadening product categories through CN coupling reactions. Huang et al. proposed to couple NO and CO2 for electrochemical urea synthesis [129]. Ten bulk metal catalysts were screened, and found Zn foil presented best. For higher performance, they synthesized zinc nanobelts (Zn NBs) catalysts through the in-situ electrochemical reduction of ZnO nanosheets (ZnO NSs). Furthermore, the electrochemical transformation process of Zn NBs was revealed by in-situ electrochemical Raman spectra and in-situ electrochemical XRD pattern. The as-prepared Zn NBs catalyst exhibited higher activity than Zn foil. The optimized FE(NH3) and yield rate of urea over Zn NBs at −0.92 VRHE in NO&CO2 saturated 0.2 M KHO3 achieved 11.26 % and 15.13 mmol·g–1·h–1, respectively (Fig. 11 ). The whole catalytic process of urea generation was also revealed through experimental and theoretical research (in-situ ATR-FTIR spectra, online DEMS measurements and DFT calculations). The CN bond was formed via the multistep coupling of *CO and *NH2 during the urea generation. This study provides more avenues for electrocatalytic urea synthesis from CO2 and NO. 4.2 Oxime Cyclohexanone oxime (CHO), as a key CN organic compound for the manufacture of nylon 6, contributes to more than 95 % of worldwide ε-caprolactam production [130,131]. Recently, Zhang et al. designed a green route for synthesizing CHO by the direct electrochemical hydrogenative coupling of NO and cyclohexanone (e-HCNC) [132]. Comparing three different cathode materials (carbon paper, Cu foam, and Pt foil), carbon paper showed the best FE(CHO) of 11 % at −0.4 VRHE. After optimizing the reaction conditions (pH and potentials), the high CHO yield rate of 10.7 mg·cm−2·h−1 with 44.8 % FE(CHO) was achieved at −0.4 VRHE and pH = 10.7. They also proved the nitrogen in CHO comes from NO by isotope-labeled experiments. Xiang et al. proposed a novel strategy for synthetic pyridine oximes using in-situ generated NH2OH from NO electrocatalytic reduction with aldehyde over a well-design nanofiber membranes (Al-NFM) [133]. With the carbon source of 2-formylpyridine, 2-pyridinealdoxime was synthesized by electrochemical methods and achieved with a Faraday efficiency up to 49.8 % and a yield of 92.1 %. As shown in Fig. 12 , the method was validated to be equally applicable to other pyridine aldehyde substrates. 4.3 Amino acids Amino acids, an essential component for proteins synthesis, play an indispensable role in the field of biological medicine and life science [134]. At present, most of the amino acids in life are produced by biological methods and Strecker synthesis [135]. More than 60 % of amino acids are produced by biological fermentation, of which glutamic acid is the most productive, followed by lysine. However, it still suffers from sterile operating conditions, long cycle, high operational costs and large amount of wastewater. Xian et al. proposed a novel strategy to co-reduce NO with 3-methyl-2-oxobutanoic acid into α-amino acids via electrochemistry in aqueous media. MOF derivative was chosen as precursors for preparing the atomically dispersed Fe catalysts (AD-Fe/NC) [136]. Based on the results of EDX, XPS and XANES, the existence of atomically dispersed Fe sites was certified in the porous N-doped carbon framework of AD-Fe/NC. The valine synthesis performance of AD-Fe/NC was served as a preliminary confirmatory experiment, and exhibited 47.4 % conversion for 3-methyl-2-oxobutanoic acid with 11.3 % selectivity of valine at −0.6 VRHE. Furthermore, based on the in-depth study of valine electrosynthesis, various α-keto acids were tested to successfully synthesize 6 kinds of amino acids by substituting 3-methyl-2-oxobutanoic (Fig. 13 ). In another study, they designed and prepared a self-standing carbon fiber membrane with CoFe alloys (CoFe-SSM) via electrospinning and then pyrolytic carbonization [137]. The electrochemical co-reduction of 4-methyl-2-oxovaleric acid and NO was selected as the research model to catalyze synthesis of leucine by CoFe-SSM. The excellent optimized activity exhibits 115.4 μmol·cm–2·h–1 yield of leucine corresponding a FE of 32.4 %, and gram yield of leucine products can be obtained within 24 h. They proposed and confirmed the reaction pathway of electrosynthesis amino acid. The adsorbed NO on CoFe-SSM is first reduced to the critical H2NOH, and further coupling 4-methyl-2-oxovaleric acid to form a key oxime intermediate, which is finally converted to leucine via subsequent reductive hydrogenation. Based on this theory, the co-electroreduction strategy was applied to synthesize over 13 kinds of amino acids by NO and α-keto acid (Fig. 14 ). The above two works expand new methods of synthesizing amino acids. 5 Challenges and perspectives 5.1 Challenges For the NORR process, the complexity of related reactions involving five-electron and multi-proton transfer for N-element makes the product selectivity difficult to control, resulting in the lack of accurate and systematic understanding for catalyst design. Under any temperature conditions, the consumption of multiple protons will greatly change the microenvironment at the interface between catalyst and electrolyte. Furthermore, using a single NO gas source is out of touch with the actual application scenario, and other components in flue gas can also affect the electrolyte, catalyst and electrocatalytic performance. Meanwhile, the oxygen evolution reaction is often used as an anode reaction, which reduces the utilization rate of electrons. Hence, based on the above issues, continuous improvement and optimization of the reaction system are indispensable in future research. To further promote the rapid development of catalyst design and product diversity in the field of NORR to value-added compounds, there are still many other challenges requiring complete solving: (1) The mechanism investigation of NO protonizing and CN coupling. (2) Establishing highly efficient and novel methods for NO enrichment and product separation. (3) Establishing and optimizing the standard evaluation and reaction system. To realize application of the NORR in future, the above issues require meticulous design of measurements, catalysts and reactors. 5.2 Perspectives Drawing on above insights, we propose all-important directions for future research, including the design of (1) catalysts, (2) electrolyte and (3) reactors. (1) Design of catalysts: the theoretical calculations as a guide are more desirable and rational to replace the traditional catalyst screening scheme. Moreover, the various catalysts for SCR process with complex scenario, such as V2O5-WO3/TiO2, CeO x and MnO x , have been studied in detail of NO adsorption and activation, which may be applied to NORR process. In particular, copper-based catalysts can effectively synthesize multi-carbon products. But single active site is not adapted to this system to activate the two substances simultaneously, the design of dual-site/dual-functional catalysts may be an effective approach to access more CN products. (2) Optimization of electrolyte: The consumption of multiple protons will greatly change the pH of the electrolyte at ambient condition, for this reason stable buffer system facilitates more stable results. At medium and high temperature, there is also an urgent need to develop better geonic conductor electrolytes. It is necessary to incorporate the optimization of electrolytes into the improvement of the entire reaction system. (3) Design of reactors: At ambient condition, the only matching unit with electrochemical NO-to-NH3 conversion in flue gas treatment is the wet desulfurization process. Therefore, it is a promising application prospects to combine NORR process with the wet desulfurization in one reactor. The choice of reactors for C-integrated NORR depend heavily on the determining steps of the reaction. For example, gas-phase systems like GDE systems are preferred with N-chain reaction as the determining steps in NO-to-urea process. Overall, each reactor type is provided with unique electrolysis environments that influence solubility, reactant transport, and diffusion rates. In summary, much effort has been devoted to research on screening catalysts of electrochemical NO-to-NH3 conversion at the theoretical and experimental levels, and demonstrated the feasibility of urea, amino acids, and cyclohexanone oxime synthesized from C-integrated electrocatalytic NO reduction. The renewable energy-driven NO conversion to the selective products of NH3 or N-containing organics represents a promising strategy to replace the existing thermochemical processes. we hope further investigations of building CN bonds via C-integrated NORR can be motivated to achieve efficient and sustainable electrosynthesis of different types of organonitrogen compounds via this review. coredata.dc:description: Nitrogen oxide (NO), one of the major air pollutants derived from the combustion of fossil fuels, has been gradually implemented with more strict emission standards in recent decades. The traditional technologies of NO removal suffer from harsher operating conditions and higher operating costs. In this case, shifting toward more eco-friendly, sustainable methods is pursued to reduce costs and increase efficiency in NO removal. With the increase of green and renewable electricity, it is a promising way to use electrochemical technology for NO conversion into more valuable chemicals, such as ammonia (NH3), urea (CH4N2O), amines and amides, etc. In this concept, researchers have made great efforts to develop different electrocatalytic systems. In this paper, we summarize the current important progress of electrocatalytic NO reduction reaction (NORR). As the concerning multi-step mechanism is complex, the priority is to screen and design efficient electrocatalysts for a certain target product. Especially for NO-to-NH3 conversion, we divide a large chapter to emphasize the advances made in mechanisms, catalyst and electrolyte. Meanwhile, the emerging CN coupling reactions for organism synthesis further drastically increases reaction complexity, as the co-reduction of two distinct reactants involves more intermediates and multiple cross-reactive pathways. The catalyst and microenvironments must be cleverly regulated and optimized to control CN bond formation. Moreover, the current challenges and future perspectives will be proposed as well to accelerate the research and development of related technologies, leading to a green and sustainable production of N-based chemicals.
coredata.dc:title: Recent advances in electrocatalytic NO reduction into ammonia and organonitrogen compounds
